leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User note:
About this chapter: Chapter 6 establishes five types of construction in which each building must be categorized. This chapter looks at the materials used in the building (combustible or noncombustible) and the extent to which building elements such as the building frame, roof, wall and floor can resist fire. Depending on the type of construction and the specific building element, fire resistance of 1 to 3 hours is specified.

diagrams.title: Exit Access & Corridor Continuity (Sprinklered, 75-120 ft)- 2021
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Keynotes:
  1. Egress through any room that may be locked is prohibited (§1016.2(3))
  2. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, non-accessory room is prohibited (§1016.2(2))
  3. Egress through an adjoining or intervening, accessory room is permitted if the egress path is clear (§1016.2(2))
  4. Egress is not permitted through kitchens, storage rooms, closets, etc. (§1016.2(5)). (Exception: mercantile stock rooms per conditions in §1016.2(5) Exception 2.)
  5. A rated corridor must lead directly to at least one exit without passing through any intervening rooms (§1020.7). See below for exceptions.
  6. An unenclosed exit access stair or ramp is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7).
  7. A foyer, lobby, reception or waiting room is not considered an "intervening room" (§1020.7 Exception 1).
  8. An enclosed elevator lobby is not considered an "intervening room" (§1016.2(1), §1020.7 Exception 2)
  9. An enclosed lobby is required at every elevator shaft unless:
    (a) the shaft is pressurized, or
    (b) "S" (smoke) label (swinging) doors are installed at the shaft openings (in addition to the sliding fire-rated doors). (§3006.2 + §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)
  10. Exit access corridors must have direct access to at least one exit not requiring passage through the enclosed elevator lobby. (§1016.2(1) + §3006.2)
  11. Rated corridors are not required for corridors serving these occupancy groups (Table 1020.2)
    Corridors which connect an elevator lobby to an exit are not required to be fire rated (§1016.2(1))
  12. (Reserved)
  13. (Reserved)
  14. (Reserved)
  15. (Reserved)
  16. (Reserved)
  17. An enclosed elevator lobby requires (nonrated) smoke partitions. (§3006.3(2))
  18. Enclosed elevator lobby doors must be self-closing "S" (smoke) label doors. (§3006.3(2) + §710.5.2.2 and §710.5.2.3)
  19. Elevator shafts require 2-hour fire barriers. (§713.4)
  20. Elevator shafts require 90-minute (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2)) automatic-closing (§716.2.6.6) fire doors. An "S" (smoke) rating is not required (or achievable for sliding doors), provided the mitigation described in Note 9 is provided. (§713.7 + Table 716.1(2) and §716.2.6.6)
  21. Enclosed exit stairways require 2-hour fire barriers. (§1023.2)
  22. Enclosed exit stairways require 90-minute self-closing fire doors with an "S" (smoke) label. (§707.6 + Table 716.1(2), §716.2.6.1, and §716.2.2.1.1-716.2.9.3)

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Structural members and assemblies that support a fire barrier are required to have the same or higher fire-resistance rating as the barrier being supported. Hollow vertical spaces within the barrier need to be fireblocked at every floor level as per Section 718.2. There is an exception for assemblies supporting fire barriers for tank storage where a maximum fire-resistance rating of 2 hours, or the minimum specified by Table 601 for the building type is required. There is an exception for construction supporting 1-hour fire barriers in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB, and VB unless mandated by other code sections.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Individual vs. Membrane Protection of Steel Beams
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where the fire-resistance rating of structural members based on construction type is required by table 601, primary steel beams must be protected by individual encasement on all sides. Secondary members associated with floor and roof assemblies may be protected by individual encasement or membrane protection.

diagrams.title: Exterior Structural Member Fire Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior load-bearing structural members located within exterior walls or outside a building must have the highest fire-resistance rating as determined by structural element and construction type per table 601or fire separation distance per table 602 whichever is highest.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

diagrams.title: Rooftop Structures:  Fire-Resistance Ratings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Roof construction and associated supports are required to comply with table 601. Where a roof supports a rooftop structure the fire-resistance rating of the roof and its associated supporting members may not be reduced by one hour as noted in table note "a".

diagrams.title: Wood Stud Walls in Type I & II Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire-retardant treated wood is allowed to be used in buildings of type I and II construction when nonbearing partitions have a required fire rating of 2 hours or less and at nonbearing exterior walls with no fire rating.

diagrams.title: Exterior Structural Member Fire Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior load-bearing structural members located within exterior walls or outside a building must have the highest fire-resistance rating as determined by structural element and construction type per table 601or fire separation distance per table 705.5 whichever is highest.

diagrams.title: Supporting Construction for Fire Partitions
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
To ensure that fire partitions are able to remain in place during emergency egress, the code requires that all structural elements that support a fire partition to be protected. The structural elements that support a fire partition are required to have a fire-resistance rating that is equal to or greater than the fire-resistance rating of the fire partition being supported. The code does provide a few exceptions to this requirement and does not require the supporting construction to be protected in buildings of Types IIB, IIIB and VB construction where the fire partition is providing any of the following:
  • Separating tenant spaces in covered and open mall buildings
  • Separating dwelling or sleeping units
  • Serving as corridor walls
  • Separating ambulatory care facilities from adjacent spaces or corridors
  • Separating dwelling and sleeping units from Group R-1 and R-2 occupancies
  • Separating vestibules from the level of exit discharge

diagrams.title: Incidental Uses - Horizontal Assemblies
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Incidental uses are required to be separated per Table 509. Where a horizontal separation is required the code requires that the separation assembly is supported by construction of equal or greater fire-resistance protection as the assembly being supported. Where the horizontal assembly is separating an incidental use in a Type IIB, IIIB or VB construction and is not required to exceed a 1 hour fire-resistance rating the construction supporting the horizontal assembly is not required to be protected.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall control the classification of buildings as to type of construction.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Openings In Ext. Walls at Lot Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The maximum area of unprotected and protected openings permitted in an exterior wall in any story of a building shall not exceed the percentages specified in Table 705.8 based on the fire separation distance of each individual story.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Mechanical Equipment Screens
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Mechanical equipment screens must typically be made of the same materials as are allowed for the building's exterior walls. Where fire separation distance exceeds 5', fire-resistance ratings are not required. The screens are generally limited to 18 feet in height above the roof, except for buildings of Type IA construction, which have no height limit. For buildings of Types I, II, III or IV construction, combustible materials may be used if specific conditions are met at roof decks, such as a minimum 20' fire separation and limited screen height, or use of fire-retardant-treated wood or ext. wall covering panels with flame spread index <25. For Type V construction at roof decks, screens may exceed the building's height limit if the fire separation distance is greater than 5' and certain material and height requirements are met, including restrictions on flame spread and the use of noncombustible or fire-retardant-treated materials.

diagrams.title: Type I / II: Exterior Areas Using Fire-Retardant Treated Wood
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings of type I or II construction that are 3 stories or less above grade plane fire-retardant treated wood may be used for the construction of balconies, porches, decks and exterior stairs that are not part of a required means of egress.

diagrams.title: Type I / II Construction:  Fire-Retardant Treated Wood Roof Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At buildings of type I or II construction, fire-retardant treated wood is permitted at roof construction. Note that fire-retardant treated wood roof construction is not permitted at buildings of type IA construction over 2 stories in height where the vertical height between top floor and roofing is less than 20'. To utilize fire-retardant treated roof construction on an I-2 Occupancy building of type I or II construction the roof must be covered by not less than a Class A roof covering and a roof assembly with a fire rating as required by the construction type.

diagrams.title: Roof Assembly Fire Classification
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A roof assembly includes all components that provide weather protection and structural support. Roof assemblies are to meet fire classification standards, Class A, B, or C, based on the building's construction type, as shown in Table 1505.1. Roof coverings must be tested per ASTM E108 or UL 790, with fire-retardant wood coverings also tested under ASTM D2898. Skylights and sloped glazing are exempt. Group U structures or small buildings under 6,000 sq ft and two stories, may use less fire-resistant materials if they meet minimum fire-separation distances.

children.body: Buildings and structures erected or to be erected, altered or extended in height or area shall be classified in one of the five construction types defined in Sections 602.2 through 602.5. The building elements shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than that specified in Table 601 and exterior walls shall have a fire-resistance rating not less than that specified in Table 705.5. Where required to have a fire-resistance rating by Table 601, building elements shall comply with the applicable provisions of Section 703.2. The protection of openings, ducts and air transfer openings in building elements shall not be required unless required by other provisions of this code.

diagrams.title: Structural Member Protection At High Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
According to Table 601, Footnote b, except in Group F-1, H, M and S-1 occupancies, fire protection of structural members in roof construction shall not be required, including protection of primary structural frame members, roof framing and decking where every part of the roof construction is 20 feet or more above any floor immediately below. Fire-retardant-treated wood members shall be allowed to be used for such unprotected members. However, be aware the 2015 codes does not include the term "primary structural frame members".

UpCodes Note: Primary structural members include columns per the definition. However, per an interpretation on June 22, 2018, regarding the 2018 codes, ICC staff opined that the columns were not part of the fire rating exemption provided by Table 601, footnote b. Per Section 704, if columns are required to be fire rated, the protection is required to extend to its connection with other structural members. Please check with your local AHJ concerning the interpretation of this issue in your locality.

diagrams.title: Combustible Projection Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A fire near a building projection will cause the heat of a fire to be trapped and has a greater chance of a building fire occurring than if it were a vertical exterior wall without a projection. Therefore, special consideration is required to be given to combustible projections.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings at Prop. Lines
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Exterior walls that have a variable distance to the property lines may have fire ratings that change across the length of wall. Also affecting the fire rating is the occupancy group adjacent to the exterior wall. Fire separation distances are measured at right angles from the face of the wall.

diagrams.title: Fire Ratings: Conc. Slabs
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per the Life Safety Code, "Fire resistance-rated floor and roof assemblies shall be classified as restrained or unrestrained in accordance with ASTM E119, Standard Test Methods for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials, or ANSI/UL 263, Standard for Fire Tests of Building Construction and Materials', or other approved test methods. The construction shall be considered restrained only where a registered design professional has furnished the authority having jurisdiction with satisfactory documentation verifying that the construction is restrained. The classification of fire resistance-rated floor and roof construction shall be identified on the plans as restrained or unrestrained."

Restraint is provided when adjacent structural elements not under the influence of a fire are able to provide lateral restraint to prevent the expansion of materials in the plane of a roof or floor assembly, such as a concrete slab, because of a fire below.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Horizontal Bldg. Separation (510.2)
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.2 provides a special condition which would allow a lesser type of construction above a Type I "podium". Sometimes there are multiple buildings over a common podium, which can be common in Group R-2 buildings.

Items that are new for 2018 codes include the allowance for vertical offsets in the horizontal assembly and a requirement for the horizontal assembly to also be Type IA construction.

diagrams.title: Ramp Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Materials for ramps allowed based on the types of construction (Types I through V) can be found in Section 602 of the building code. Generally, Types I and II require non-combustible materials (i.e. steel and concrete), while Types III, IV and V generally allow combustible materials. However, wood handrails (not guards) are allowed in all types of construction.

children.body: A building or portion thereof shall not be required to conform to the details of a type of construction higher than that type which meets the minimum requirements based on occupancy even though certain features of such a building actually conform to a higher type of construction.

Types I and II construction are those types of construction in which the building elements specified in Table 601 are of noncombustible materials, except as permitted in Section 603 and elsewhere in this code.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 1
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours. Per 704.1 any structure supporting the first floor assembly would likewise also need to have the same 1-1/2 hour fire protection rating.

diagrams.title: Group R-1 & R-2 Bldgs Type IIA - Height Increase Pt 2
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The code provides for special provisions for additional height and number of stories when additional fire protection measures as prescribed by the code are provided. For group R-1 and R-2 buildings of type IIA construction the height limitations may be increased to 9 stories and 100 feet when the following additional fire protection measures are part of the design. The fire separation distance to all lot lines or to any other building on the lot must be not less than 50". The exits from each floor must also be segregated from each other in an area enclosed by a 2 hour fire-resistance rated fire wall. The first floor assembly must have a fire-resistance rating of not less than 1-1/2 hours.

Type IIA Construction

Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Unlimited Area Paint Hangers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Aircraft paint hangars can be unlimited in area if they are classified as a Group H-2, are no more than one story above grade, and meet all the requirements of Section 412.5.

diagrams.title: Wood Veneer on Non-Combustible Wall Construction
Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Allowable Height Above Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The allowable building height is measured from grade plane. If the average roof height, measured from grade plane, is less than the height from grade, then the building will comply. In this case, a Type II-B building with an NFPA 13 sprinkler system and with a Group B occupancy is on a sloping site. Since the average roof height is 61 feet above grade plane, and the maximum allowable height is 75 feet, then the building will comply.

diagrams.title: Wood Stud Walls in Type I & II Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire-retardant treated wood is allowed to be used in buildings of type I and II construction when nonbearing partitions have a required fire rating of 2 hours or less and at nonbearing exterior walls with no fire rating.

diagrams.title: Type I / II: Exterior Areas Using Fire-Retardant Treated Wood
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings of type I or II construction that are 3 stories or less above grade plane fire-retardant treated wood may be used for the construction of balconies, porches, decks and exterior stairs that are not part of a required means of egress.

diagrams.title: Type I / II Construction:  Fire-Retardant Treated Wood Roof Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At buildings of type I or II construction, fire-retardant treated wood is permitted at roof construction. Note that fire-retardant treated wood roof construction is not permitted at buildings of type IA construction over 2 stories in height where the vertical height between top floor and roofing is less than 20'. To utilize fire-retardant treated roof construction on an I-2 Occupancy building of type I or II construction the roof must be covered by not less than a Class A roof covering and a roof assembly with a fire rating as required by the construction type.

children.body: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

diagrams.title: Podiums: Type IIIA Height Increase (2021)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Although the provisions of Section 510.5 do not address sprinkler system use, the new (2021) limitations for use of NFPA 13R systems to 4 stories and 30 feet would preclude the use of NFPA 13R for a full height Type III-A building. In addition, non-sprinklered new construction for Group R occupancy is not permitted. Therefore, an NFPA 13 system would be required for this condition.

diagrams.title: Combustibles on Non-Combustible Ext. Walls: Limitations
Wood Veneer on Non-Combustible Wall Construction
Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

diagrams.title: Type IIIB Const.
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

Significant exceptions exist in Section 602.3 for buildings of certain occupancies and in fire districts.

diagrams.title: Type IIIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Type III construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of any material permitted by this code. Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies of a 2-hour rating or less.

children.body:
Type IV construction is that type of construction in which the building elements are mass timber or noncombustible materials and have fire-resistance ratings in accordance with Table 601. Mass timber elements shall meet the fire-resistance-rating requirements of this section based on either the fire-resistance rating of the noncombustible protection, the mass timber, or a combination of both and shall be determined in accordance with Section 703.2. The minimum dimensions and permitted materials for building elements shall comply with the provisions of this section and Section 2304.11. Mass timber elements of Types IV-A, IV-B and IV-C construction shall be protected with noncombustible protection applied directly to the mass timber in accordance with Sections 602.4.1 through 602.4.3. The time assigned to the noncombustible protection shall be determined in accordance with Section 703.6 and comply with Section 722.7.
Cross-laminated timber shall be labeled as conforming to ANSI/APA PRG 320 as referenced in Section 2303.1.4.
Exterior load-bearing walls and nonload-bearing walls shall be mass timber construction, or shall be of noncombustible construction.
Exception: Exterior load-bearing walls and nonload-bearing walls of Type IV-HT Construction in accordance with Section 602.4.4.
The interior building elements, including nonload-bearing walls and partitions, shall be of mass timber construction or of noncombustible construction.
Exception: Interior building elements and nonload-bearing walls and partitions of Type IV-HT construction in accordance with Section 602.4.4.
Combustible concealed spaces are not permitted except as otherwise indicated in Sections 602.4.1 through 602.4.4. Combustible stud spaces within light frame walls of Type IV-HT construction shall not be considered concealed spaces, but shall comply with Section 718.
In buildings of Type IV-A, IV-B, and IV-C construction with an occupied floor located more than 75 feet (22 860 mm) above the lowest level of fire department access, up to and including 12 stories or 180 feet (54 864 mm) above grade plane, mass timber interior exit and elevator hoistway enclosures shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2. In buildings greater than 12 stories or 180 feet (54 864 mm) above grade plane, interior exit and elevator hoistway enclosures shall be constructed of noncombustible materials.

diagrams.title: Combustibles on Non-Combustible Ext. Walls: Limitations
Wood Veneer on Non-Combustible Wall Construction
Podiums: Parking Beneath Group R
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Section 510.4 allows for the increase of one story above a Type I closed/open garage or Type IV open garage with a horizontal assembly with a fire resistive rating equal to that of 508.4 or the required type of construction, whichever is greater. Section 406.5.3 allows open parking garages complying with 510.4 to be mixed use occupancies. Depending on the other occupancy groups below the R occupancy it is possible areas could require a greater fire-resistance rating than is required for the type of construction.

Some literature suggests that a lesser rating can be applied to the floor of type IV construction. However, the wording of the code section does not seem to provide that option. Heavy timber construction for floors is based on a prescriptive size of wood members. Mass timber construction requires a minimum floor rating of 2 hours, and only footnote a of Table 601 allows for reduction of ratings of a floor rating. It does not appear the code allows for reduction of the floor rating to 1 hour, as some suggest.

The user should also be aware that starting with the 2021 year edition, sections of 903.3.1.2 more severely restricts the use of NFPA 13R systems for this condition to the grade plane, instead of the horizontal assembly above the garage.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

diagrams.title: Heavy Timber Construction - Member Sizes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Heavy timber, or Type IV-HT construction, provides fire rated construction by providing a large enough wood member for the charring of the material to insulate the rest of the structural member. In order to be considered heavy timber construction of Type IV-HT, columns, beams, joists and decking must be a minimum depth and thickness. Refer to Table 601 for additional fire rating requirements for heavy timber (Type IV-HT) construction.

children.body: Building elements in Type IV-A construction shall be protected in accordance with Sections 602.4.1.1 through 602.4.1.6. The required fire-resistance rating of noncombustible elements and protected mass timber elements shall be determined in accordance with Section 703.2.

The outside face of exterior walls of mass timber construction shall be protected with noncombustible protection with a minimum assigned time of 40 minutes, as specified in Table 722.7.1(1). Components of the exterior wall covering shall be of noncombustible material except water-resistive barriers having a peak heat release rate of less than 150kW/m2, a total heat release of less than 20 MJ/m2 and an effective heat of combustion of less than 18MJ/kg as determined in accordance with ASTM E1354 and having a flame spread index of 25 or less and a smoke-developed index of 450 or less as determined in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. The ASTM E1354 test shall be conducted on specimens at the thickness intended for use, in the horizontal orientation and at an incident radiant heat flux of 50 kW/m2.
Interior faces of all mass timber elements, including the inside faces of exterior mass timber walls and mass timber roofs, shall be protected with materials complying with Section 703.3.

Noncombustible protection shall contribute a time equal to or greater than times assigned in Table 722.7.1(1), but not less than 80 minutes. The use of materials and their respective protection contributions specified in Table 722.7.1(2) shall be permitted to be used for compliance with Section 722.7.1.

The floor assembly shall contain a noncombustible material not less than 1 inch (25 mm) in thickness above the mass timber. Floor finishes in accordance with Section 804 shall be permitted on top of the noncombustible material. The underside of floor assemblies shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.

The interior surfaces of roof assemblies shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2. Roof coverings in accordance with Chapter 15 shall be permitted on the outside surface of the roof assembly.

Concealed spaces shall not contain combustibles other than electrical, mechanical, fire protection, or plumbing materials and equipment permitted in plenums in accordance with Section 602 of the International Mechanical Code, and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Section 718. Combustible construction forming concealed spaces shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.

diagrams.title: Plenum (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A plenum is an enclosed portion of the building structure, other than an occupiable space being conditioned, that is designed to allow air movement, and thereby serve as part of an air distribution system. The Life Safety Code further defines that at least one duct connects to this component.

diagrams.title: Plenums: General Requirements
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The mechanical code allows the following spaces to be utilized as plenums for supply, return, exhaust and relief ventilation purposes:
  • Uninhabited crawl spaces
  • Areas above a ceiling
  • Areas below a floor
  • Uninhabited attic spaces
  • Mechanical equipment rooms
The mechanical code allows wall stud cavity spaces and the spaces between solid floor joists to be utilized as plenums for return, exhaust and relief ventilation purposes when in compliance with section 602.3. Appliances installed within plenums may not be fuel-fired appliances.

diagrams.title: Concealed Spaces Not Requiring Sprinkler Protection
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Small openings with both of the following limits shall be permitted:
  1. A combined total area of not more than 20 percent of the ceiling, construction feature, or plane shall be used to determine the boundaries of the concealed space.
  2. Gaps greater than 4 ft (1.2 m) long shall not be more than 8 in. (200 mm) wide.

children.body: Shafts shall be permitted in accordance with Sections 713 and 718. Both the shaft side and room side of mass timber elements shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.

Building elements in Type IV-B construction shall be protected in accordance with Sections 602.4.2.1 through 602.4.2.6. The required fire-resistance rating of noncombustible elements or mass timber elements shall be determined in accordance with Section 703.2.

The outside face of exterior walls of mass timber construction shall be protected with noncombustible protection with a minimum assigned time of 40 minutes, as specified in Table 722.7.1(1). Components of the exterior wall covering shall be of noncombustible material except water-resistive barriers having a peak heat release rate of less than 150kW/m2, a total heat release of less than 20 MJ/m2 and an effective heat of combustion of less than 18MJ/kg as determined in accordance with ASTM E1354, and having a flame spread index of 25 or less and a smoke-developed index of 450 or less as determined in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. The ASTM E1354 test shall be conducted on specimens at the thickness intended for use, in the horizontal orientation and at an incident radiant heat flux of 50 kW/m2.

Interior faces of all mass timber elements, including the inside face of exterior mass timber walls and mass timber roofs, shall be protected, as required by this section, with materials complying with Section 703.3.

Noncombustible protection shall contribute a time equal to or greater than times assigned in Table 722.7.1(1), but not less than 80 minutes. The use of materials and their respective protection contributions specified in Table 722.7.1(2) shall be permitted to be used for compliance with Section 722.7.1.

Interior faces of mass timber elements, including the inside face of exterior mass timber walls and mass timber roofs, shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.2.2.1.
Exceptions: Unprotected portions of mass timber ceilings and walls complying with Section 602.4.2.2.4 and the following:
  1. Unprotected portions of mass timber ceilings and walls complying with one of the following:
    1. Unprotected portions of mass timber ceilings, including attached beams, shall be permitted and shall be limited to an area equal to 20 percent of the floor area in any dwelling unit or fire area.
    2. Unprotected portions of mass timber walls, including attached columns, shall be permitted and shall be limited to an area equal to 40 percent of the floor area in any dwelling unit or fire area.
    3. Unprotected portions of both walls and ceilings of mass timber, including attached columns and beams, in any dwelling unit or fire area shall be permitted in accordance with Section 602.4.2.2.3.
  2. Mass timber columns and beams that are not an integral portion of walls or ceilings, respectively, shall be permitted to be unprotected without restriction of either aggregate area or separation from one another.

In each dwelling unit or fire area, where both portions of ceilings and portions of walls are unprotected, the total allowable unprotected area shall be determined in accordance with Equation 6-1.
(Equation 6-1)
where:
Utc = Total unprotected mass timber ceiling areas.
Uac = Allowable unprotected mass timber ceiling area conforming to Exception 1.1 of Section 602.4.2.2.2.
Utw = Total unprotected mass timber wall areas.
Uaw = Allowable unprotected mass timber wall area conforming to Exception 1.2 of Section 602.4.2.2.2.

In each dwelling unit or fire area, unprotected portions of mass timber walls and ceilings shall be not less than 15 feet (4572 mm) from unprotected portions of other walls and ceilings, measured horizontally along the ceiling and from other unprotected portions of walls measured horizontally along the floor.
children.displayTitle: 602.4.2.2.4 Separation Distance Between Unprotected Mass Timber Elements
children.titleText: Separation Distance Between Unprotected Mass Timber Elements

children.body: The floor assembly shall contain a noncombustible material not less than 1 inch (25 mm) in thickness above the mass timber. Floor finishes in accordance with Section 804 shall be permitted on top of the noncombustible material. The underside of floor assemblies shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.

The interior surfaces of roof assemblies shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.2.2 except, in nonoccupiable spaces, they shall be treated as a concealed space with no portion left unprotected. Roof coverings in accordance with Chapter 15 shall be permitted on the outside surface of the roof assembly.

Concealed spaces shall not contain combustibles other than electrical, mechanical, fire protection, or plumbing materials and equipment permitted in plenums in accordance with Section 602 of the International Mechanical Code, and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Section 718. Combustible construction forming concealed spaces shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.
Shafts shall be permitted in accordance with Sections 713 and 718. Both the shaft side and room side of mass timber elements shall be protected in accordance with Section 602.4.1.2.

Building elements in Type IV-C construction shall be protected in accordance with Sections 602.4.3.1 through 602.4.3.6. The required fire-resistance rating of building elements shall be determined in accordance with Section 703.2.

The exterior side of walls of combustible construction shall be protected with noncombustible protection with a minimum assigned time of 40 minutes, as determined in Table 722.7.1(1). Components of the exterior wall covering shall be of noncombustible material except water-resistive barriers having a peak heat release rate of less than 150 kW/m2, a total heat release of less than 20 MJ/m2 and an effective heat of combustion of less than 18 MJ/kg as determined in accordance with ASTM E1354 and having a flame spread index of 25 or less and a smoke-developed index of 450 or less as determined in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. The ASTM E1354 test shall be conducted on specimens at the thickness intended for use, in the horizontal orientation and at an incident radiant heat flux of 50 kW/m2.
Mass timber elements are permitted to be unprotected.
Floor finishes in accordance with Section 804 shall be permitted on top of the floor construction.
Roof coverings in accordance with Chapter 15 shall be permitted on the outside surface of the roof assembly.

Concealed spaces shall not contain combustibles other than electrical, mechanical, fire protection, or plumbing materials and equipment permitted in plenums in accordance with Section 602 of the International Mechanical Code, and shall comply with all applicable provisions of Section 718. Combustible construction forming concealed spaces shall be protected with noncombustible protection with a minimum assigned time of 40 minutes, as specified in Table 722.7.1(1).

diagrams.title: Plenum (definition)
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A plenum is an enclosed portion of the building structure, other than an occupiable space being conditioned, that is designed to allow air movement, and thereby serve as part of an air distribution system. The Life Safety Code further defines that at least one duct connects to this component.

children.body: Shafts shall be permitted in accordance with Sections 713 and 718. Shafts and elevator hoistway and interior exit stairway enclosures shall be protected with noncombustible protection with a minimum assigned time of 40 minutes, as specified in Table 722.7.1(1), on both the inside of the shaft and the outside of the shaft.

Type IV-HT (Heavy Timber) construction is that type of construction in which the exterior walls are of noncombustible materials and the interior building elements are of solid wood, laminated heavy timber or structural composite lumber (SCL), without concealed spaces or with concealed spaces complying with Section 602.4.4.3. The minimum dimensions for permitted materials including solid timber, glued-laminated timber, SCL and cross-laminated timber (CLT) and the details of Type IV construction shall comply with the provisions of this section and Section 2304.11. Exterior walls complying with Section 602.4.4.1 or 602.4.4.2 shall be permitted. Interior walls and partitions not less than 1-hour fire-resistance rated or heavy timber conforming with Section 2304.11.2.2 shall be permitted.
Fire-retardant-treated wood framing and sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies with a 2-hour rating or less.

Cross-laminated timber (CLT) not less than 4 inches (102 mm) in thickness complying with Section 2303.1.4 shall be permitted within exterior wall assemblies with a 2-hour rating or less. Heavy timber structural members appurtenant to the CLT exterior wall shall meet the requirements of Table 2304.11 and be fire-resistance rated as required for the exterior wall. The exterior surface of the cross-laminated timber and heavy timber elements shall be protected by one the following:
  1. Fire-retardant-treated wood sheathing complying with Section 2303.2 and not less than 15/32 inch (12 mm) thick.
  2. Gypsum board not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) thick.
  3. A noncombustible material.

Concealed spaces shall not contain combustible materials other than building elements and electrical, mechanical, fire protection, or plumbing materials and equipment permitted in plenums in accordance with Section 602 of the International Mechanical Code. Concealed spaces shall comply with applicable provisions of Section 718. Concealed spaces shall be protected in accordance with one or more of the following:
  1. The building shall be sprinklered throughout in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 and automatic sprinklers shall also be provided in the concealed space.
  2. The concealed space shall be completely filled with noncombustible insulation.
  3. Surfaces within the concealed space shall be fully sheathed with not less than 5/8-inch Type X gypsum board.
Exception: Concealed spaces within interior walls and partitions with a 1-hour or greater fire-resistance rating complying with Section 2304.11.2.2 shall not require additional protection.

Where a horizontal separation of 20 feet (6096 mm) or more is provided, wood columns and arches conforming to heavy timber sizes complying with Section 2304.11 shall be permitted to be used externally.

diagrams.title: Heavy Timber Construction - Member Sizes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Heavy timber, or Type IV-HT construction, provides fire rated construction by providing a large enough wood member for the charring of the material to insulate the rest of the structural member. In order to be considered heavy timber construction of Type IV-HT, columns, beams, joists and decking must be a minimum depth and thickness. Refer to Table 601 for additional fire rating requirements for heavy timber (Type IV-HT) construction.

children.body: Type V construction is that type of construction in which the structural elements, exterior walls and interior walls are of any materials permitted by this code.

diagrams.title: Fireblocking, Draftstopping and Enclosed Space Concepts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fireblocking: Building materials, or materials approved for use as fireblocking, installed to resist the free passage of flame to other areas of the building through concealed spaces.

Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

In the course of construction concealed spaces are created that could facilitate the passage of fire. Section 718 defines where and how the free passage of fire through concealed spaces must be slowed or stopped by the use of fireblocking and draftstops. Where horizontal and vertical concealed spaces meet and in relatively small concealed spaces such as in enclosed wall cavities the code calls for continuous fireblocking at various critical intersections and spacings to slow the spread of fire depending on the concealed space condition. In larger concealed spaces such as attics the code calls for draftstopping at specific intervals or spacing to slow the spread of fire. The materials acceptable for use as fireblocking are defined in Section 718.2.1. The materials acceptable for use as draftstopping are defined in Section 718.3.1.

diagrams.title: Cricket (Unrated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Crickets at property lines may be able to be unrated if less than 30" max. height and the roof sheathing for a 4 foot distance on each side is fire-retardant treated. Check with local jurisdictions for suitability and applicability.

Source: 2019 Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.6.3 - "Unrated cricket less than or equal to 30 inches."

diagrams.title: Cricket (Rated) at Prop. Line
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a large wood framed cricket when required.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Wood Cricket Greater Than 30" in Height"

diagrams.title: Sprinklers: Combustible Stairway Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When stairwells are constructed of combustible construction they must be fully sprinklered. Sprinklers are required to be installed under every stairway, at the top of the shaft, beneath each landing, and at the lowest intermediate landing.

diagrams.title: NFPA 13R Sprinklers: Balconies and Decks
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a residential building is constructed of Type V construction or where the balconies, decks, or patios are built to section 705.2.3.1, exception 3 of the building code, then those covered balconies, decks, or patios are required to have sprinkler protection. Sprinkler heads must be between 1"-6" below structural members, and can be a maximum of 14" below the deck covering above.

diagrams.title: Fire Walls: Vertical Continuity - Base Condition
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In certain cases a fire wall is not required to start at the foundation or to terminate 30" above an adjacent roof. The code allows for fire walls to terminate at the underside of the roof sheathing or deck provided it is adequately protected. Other exceptions also apply.

diagrams.title: Fire Assembly Continuity: Framed Roof
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
This is but one way to provide a continuous fire rated assembly at a wood framed roof attic enclosure.

Source: Oregon Residential Specialty Code Section R302.2.3.1 - "Fire-resistance-rated Roof/Ceiling Construction - "Mushroom" Attic Enclosure Framing Parallel to Common Property Line"

diagrams.title: Combustible Materials in Concealed Spaces in Type I or II Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Noncombustible materials per table 601 are required for Type I and II construction. Combustible materials are allowed to be utilized in concealed spaces per the exceptions provided in section 718.5 as listed below:
  1. Per Section 603 (this section covers insulation, roofing, millwork and many typical finishes)
  2. Materials in plenums per section 602 of the Mechanical Code
  3. Class A finishes per section 803
  4. Piping within partitions or shafts
  5. Piping within ceiling spaces per the Mechanical Code
  6. Pipe insulation and coverings not within a plenum per 720.7

diagrams.title: Type I / II: Exterior Areas Using Fire-Retardant Treated Wood
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings of type I or II construction that are 3 stories or less above grade plane fire-retardant treated wood may be used for the construction of balconies, porches, decks and exterior stairs that are not part of a required means of egress.

diagrams.title: Type I / II Construction:  Fire-Retardant Treated Wood Roof Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At buildings of type I or II construction, fire-retardant treated wood is permitted at roof construction. Note that fire-retardant treated wood roof construction is not permitted at buildings of type IA construction over 2 stories in height where the vertical height between top floor and roofing is less than 20'. To utilize fire-retardant treated roof construction on an I-2 Occupancy building of type I or II construction the roof must be covered by not less than a Class A roof covering and a roof assembly with a fire rating as required by the construction type.

diagrams.title: Roof Assembly Fire Classification
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A roof assembly includes all components that provide weather protection and structural support. Roof assemblies are to meet fire classification standards, Class A, B, or C, based on the building's construction type, as shown in Table 1505.1. Roof coverings must be tested per ASTM E108 or UL 790, with fire-retardant wood coverings also tested under ASTM D2898. Skylights and sloped glazing are exempt. Group U structures or small buildings under 6,000 sq ft and two stories, may use less fire-resistant materials if they meet minimum fire-separation distances.

diagrams.title: Combustible Water Resistive Barriers
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a building is over 40" tall above grade plane, is of types I, II, II or IV construction and is greater than 40' tall above grade plane, if the water-resistive barrier (WRB) is combustible it must be tested and comply with the criteria of NFPA 285. Combustibility of the WRB is determined by section 703.3. Fenestrations, and flashings are not considered part of the WRB in determining where a combustible WRB is permitted. The Code allows for a combustible WRB without NFPA 285 compliance where the WRB is the only combustible wall component and the siding is brick, concrete, stone, terra cotta, stucco or steel with minimum thicknesses in accordance with Table 1404.2. The Code also allows for a combustible WRB without NFPA 285 compliance where the WRB is the only combustible wall component and has the following characteristics: Flame spread index ≤25, smoke-developed index ≤450, peak heat release rate <150 kW/m2, total heat release of less than 20 MJ/m2, and an effective heat of combustion of less than 18 MJ/kg.

children.displayTitle: Section 603 Combustible Material in Types I and II Construction
children.titleText: Combustible Material in Types I and II Construction

children.body:
Combustible materials shall be permitted in buildings of Type I or II construction in the following applications and in accordance with Sections 603.1.1 through 603.1.3:
  1. Fire-retardant-treated wood shall be permitted in:
    1. Nonbearing partitions where the required fire-resistance rating is 2 hours or less except in shaft enclosures within Group I-2 occupancies and ambulatory care facilities.
    2. Nonbearing exterior walls where fire-resistance-rated construction is not required.
    3. Roof construction, including girders, trusses, framing and decking.
      Exceptions:
      1. In buildings of Type IA construction exceeding two stories above grade plane, fire-retardant-treated wood is not permitted in roof construction where the vertical distance from the upper floor to the roof is less than 20 feet (6096 mm).
      2. Group I-2, roof construction containing fire-retardant-treated wood shall be covered by not less than a Class A roof covering or roof assembly, and the roof assembly shall have a fire-resistance rating where required by the construction type.
    4. Balconies, porches, decks and exterior stairways not used as required exits on buildings three stories or less above grade plane.
  2. Thermal and acoustical insulation, other than foam plastics, having a flame spread index of not more than 25.
    Exceptions:
    1. Insulation placed between two layers of noncombustible materials without an intervening airspace shall be allowed to have a flame spread index of not more than 100.
    2. Insulation installed between a finished floor and solid decking without intervening airspace shall be allowed to have a flame spread index of not more than 200.
  3. Foam plastics in accordance with Chapter 26.
  4. Roof coverings that have an A, B or C classification.
  5. Interior floor finish and floor covering materials installed in accordance with Section 804.
  6. Millwork such as doors, door frames, window sashes and frames.
  7. Interior wall and ceiling finishes installed in accordance with Section 803.
  8. Trim installed in accordance with Section 806.
  9. Where not installed greater than 15 feet (4572 mm) above grade, show windows, nailing or furring strips and wooden bulkheads below show windows, including their frames, aprons and show cases.
  10. Finish flooring installed in accordance with Section 805.
  11. Partitions dividing portions of stores, offices or similar places occupied by one tenant only and that do not establish a corridor serving an occupant load of 30 or more shall be permitted to be constructed of fire-retardant-treated wood, 1-hour fire-resistance-rated construction or of wood panels or similar light construction up to 6 feet (1829 mm) in height.
  12. Stages and platforms constructed in accordance with Sections 410.2 and 410.3, respectively.
  13. Combustible exterior wall coverings, balconies and similar projections and bay or oriel windows in accordance with Chapter 14 and Section 705.2.3.1.
  14. Blocking such as for handrails, millwork, cabinets and window and door frames.
  15. Light-transmitting plastics as permitted by Chapter 26.
  16. Mastics and caulking materials applied to provide flexible seals between components of exterior wall construction.
  17. Exterior plastic veneer installed in accordance with Section 2605.2.
  18. Nailing or furring strips as permitted by Section 803.15.
  19. Heavy timber as permitted by Note c to Table 601 and Sections 602.4.4.4 and 705.2.3.1.
  20. Aggregates, component materials and admixtures as permitted by Section 703.2.1.2.
  21. Sprayed fire-resistant materials and intumescent and mastic fire-resistant coatings, determined on the basis of fire resistance tests in accordance with Section 703.2 and installed in accordance with Sections 1705.15 and 1705.16, respectively.
  22. Materials used to protect penetrations in fire-resistance-rated assemblies in accordance with Section 714.
  23. Materials used to protect joints in fire-resistance-rated assemblies in accordance with Section 715.
  24. Materials allowed in the concealed spaces of buildings of Types I and II construction in accordance with Section 718.5.
  25. Materials exposed within plenums complying with Section 602 of the International Mechanical Code.
  26. Wall construction of freezers and coolers of less than 1,000 square feet (92.9 m2), in size, lined on both sides with noncombustible materials and the building is protected throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1.
  27. Wood nailers for parapet flashing and roof cants.

diagrams.title: Direct Attachment & Furred Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces behind furred construction can be areas where fire and smoke can propagate. To prevent this, fireblocking or the use of certain kinds of insulation are installed. Alternatively, using non-combustible materials in the concealed spaces can be used, or the finish should be applied directly to the wall surface. When non-combustible construction is chosen, be careful not to allow or specify the use of combustible data cabling or other items to use the open space as a chase. Other materials in this space should meet the Class A ratings of Section 803.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

diagrams.title: Type IIA Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIA ("Two-A") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "A" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are required to be fire-rated construction.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Type IIB Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Type IIB ("Two-B") construction is classified as non-combustible construction. The "B" portion of the construction type generally denotes that primary elements of the building are not required to be fire-rated construction. Exceptions may exist, such as walls close to a property line or a neighboring building.

Use of any combustible materials in Type I or II construction is regulated by Section 603, and includes more than just wood materials, such as combustible data cabling, which could be installed after occupancy in a non-compliant manner.

diagrams.title: Wood Stud Walls in Type I & II Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Fire-retardant treated wood is allowed to be used in buildings of type I and II construction when nonbearing partitions have a required fire rating of 2 hours or less and at nonbearing exterior walls with no fire rating.

diagrams.title: Type I / II: Exterior Areas Using Fire-Retardant Treated Wood
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In buildings of type I or II construction that are 3 stories or less above grade plane fire-retardant treated wood may be used for the construction of balconies, porches, decks and exterior stairs that are not part of a required means of egress.

diagrams.title: Type I / II Construction:  Fire-Retardant Treated Wood Roof Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At buildings of type I or II construction, fire-retardant treated wood is permitted at roof construction. Note that fire-retardant treated wood roof construction is not permitted at buildings of type IA construction over 2 stories in height where the vertical height between top floor and roofing is less than 20'. To utilize fire-retardant treated roof construction on an I-2 Occupancy building of type I or II construction the roof must be covered by not less than a Class A roof covering and a roof assembly with a fire rating as required by the construction type.

children.body: The use of nonmetallic ducts shall be permitted where installed in accordance with the limitations of the International Mechanical Code.
The use of combustible piping materials shall be permitted where installed in accordance with the limitations of the International Mechanical Code and the International Plumbing Code.
The use of electrical wiring methods with combustible insulation, tubing, raceways and related components shall be permitted where installed in accordance with the limitations of this code.
